response: The Taliban's military offensive against the government of Afghanistan and its allies continues with the capture of Zaranj, the provincial capital of Nimruz Province, marking the first time the group captured a major provincial city since the 2001 invasion. Local police spokesperson confirmed the city has fallen under the group’s control and blamed the central government's lack of reinforcement of military. As of July 2021, the Taliban has seized 148 districts from the Afghan government, and around 50% of Afghanistan is under their control, while the fight for some of the remaining cities and territories continues. The situation has raised concerns about the safety of civilians and the potential for a humanitarian crisis, with reports of civilians fleeing their homes to escape the fighting. The international community has been closely watching the situation, with some offering support and

Wildfires in Greece have resulted in mass evacuations in the northern suburbs of Athens due to the flames still burning outside the capital. Sadly, this tragedy resulted in the death of a fallen electricity pylon, resulting in the death of a volunteer firefighter, and a man died in a factory. The wildfires have also caused injuries to twenty more people. Areas such as Attica, Olympia, Messenia, and Euboea have witnessed the largest wildfires to date.

The ongoing global pandemic of COVID-19 caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) continues to affect Queensland with new updates. On August 2, Cairns and Yarrabah were placed under a three-day lockdown after a taxi driver from Kanimbla tested positive for the virus. The driver was infectious for ten days and had transported passengers in Far North Queensland, leading to concerns of potential community transmission. Queensland's Chief Health Officer has urged anyone with symptoms or who has been to a Queensland Health exposure site to get tested immediately. Despite this, Queensland has managed to maintain a low fatality rate throughout the pandemic, with only seven recorded deaths as of the end of July 2021. The government has implemented measures such as border restrictions, mandatory masks, and periodic lockdowns to contain any outbreaks and control the spread of the virus.

The COVID-19 pandemic in Palau initially involved the implementation of strict border controls and quarantine measures, with the first case only being reported in May 2021. However, the country's vaccination efforts have yielded impressive results, with an estimated 96% of adults being fully vaccinated by May 26, and the 80% vaccination rate among the population aged 12 and above achieving herd immunity. As a result, tourism has reopened in the country, and plans are underway to vaccinate adolescents from 12 to 17. Palau's success in containing the virus can be attributed to its early and effective response, as well as its ongoing vaccination campaign.

Egypt-Russia relations have a long and complex history, dating back before the 16th century when Russia provided support to the Greek Orthodox Church of Alexandria. In modern times, relations were strengthened during the Nasser era, but became strained after the reorientation of Egypt toward the West under Anwar Sadat. However, they improved significantly after the removal of Mohamed Morsi from office in 2013, with both countries working to strengthen military and trade ties. The resumption of direct commercial flights between Russia and Egypt for the first time since the 2015 Metrojet Flight 9268 bombing that killed mostly Russian tourists marks a significant milestone. In recent years, both countries have signed various agreements, including the construction of Egypt's first nuclear reactor and the establishment of a "Russian Industrial Zone" along the Suez Canal. Furthermore, Egypt has reportedly dispatched troops to assist the Syrian government, while Russia's Wagner Group is supporting the House of Representatives in the ongoing Libyan Civil War.

The 2021 Algeria wildfires have continued to devastate the northern region of the country, with a death toll of 65 (37 civilians and 28 soldiers) and a total of 69 fires raging on for four consecutive days. The fires, which started on 9 August 2021, have destroyed Mediterranean trees, killed livestock, and left many villages struggling with limited water. Despite efforts from Algerian authorities to send soldiers to aid with evacuations, many citizens have still had to fend off the flames themselves with rudimentary tools. In response to the tragically high loss of life, President Abdelmadjid Tebboune has declared three days of national mourning for the victims. Unfortunately, firefighting aircraft remains unavailable in the region.

The Lebanese liquidity crisis, which began in August 2019 and was further worsened by the COVID-19 pandemic and the 2020 Beirut port explosion, has seen the black market exchange rate rise substantially due to acute USD shortages. Since October 2019, the Lebanese pound has fallen to around a third of its value, leading to a significant increase in inflation, a loss of purchasing power, and increased poverty. The crisis has also affected the ability to pay for imports, forcing people to turn to black markets. The latest development is the decision by the Central Bank of Lebanon to end fuel subsidies, which will result in a significant increase in fuel prices. The World Bank has warned that the country's economic crisis could become one of the three most severe since the mid-19th century if reforms are not implemented.

On September 20, 2021, Canadians will be going to the polls to elect members of the House of Commons to the 44th Canadian Parliament. This election was called earlier than scheduled by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, who asked Governor General Mary Simon to dissolve parliament on August 15, 2021. The current government is a minority government, and the election will determine whether the Liberal Party led by Trudeau will be able to maintain their power, or if the Conservative Party, led by Erin O'Toole, will take over. The outcome of this election will have significant implications on issues such as pandemic management, climate change, and the economy.

The Panjshir conflict began as a political dispute between the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan and the Taliban following the Fall of Kabul in 2021. As of August 2021, the Panjshir Valley, largely contiguous with Panjshir Province, is the only region out of the Taliban's control. Panjshiris had been moving military equipment, including helicopters and armored vehicles, into Panjshir Province and were joined by commanders of the Afghan National Army Commando Corps. On August 17, 2021, Amrullah Saleh declared himself President of Afghanistan from the Panjshir Valley and vowed to continue military operations against the Taliban from there. His claim to the presidency was endorsed by Ahmad Massoud and Islamic Republic of Afghanistan Minister of Defence Bismillah Mohammadi. Recently, Russian intelligence sources reported that Panjshir resistance forces loyal to Saleh had managed to re-capture Charikar and the surrounding areas of Parwan Province from the Taliban. However, a negotiated end to the political impasse is still being discussed.

The 2021 Niger attacks continue to ravage the country with the most recent attack on a mosque in the village of Theim resulting in the deaths of 16 people. This adds to the ongoing series of attacks by militants on civilians and soldiers in Niger, mainly in the western region of Tillabéri, which have left over 400 people dead and more than 100 others injured this year alone. The attackers are Islamist militants who arrived in the villages crossing from neighboring countries, and although several major attacks occurred in Niger during the 2010s and 2020, this is the first time that over 100 civilians were killed in single incidents. The exact terrorist organization behind these attacks remains unclear. These attacks come amidst Niger's municipal and regional elections, and President Mohamed Bazoum has condemned the attacks and declared three days of national mourning.

Operation Allies Refuge, the United States military operation to airlift at-risk Afghan civilians, particularly interpreters, U.S. embassy employees, and other prospective Special Immigrant Visa (SIV) applicants, has successfully evacuated 17,000 people, including 2,500 Americans, according to United States Army major general William D. Taylor. The operation was launched concurrently with the larger American military withdrawal from Afghanistan and has been ongoing since July 14, with the first group of 200 Afghan interpreters arriving at Fort Lee, Virginia, for SIV processing on July 30. Following the deterioration of the situation in Afghanistan on August 12, the Biden administration announced the deployment of 3,000 U.S. troops to secure the evacuation of embassy personnel, U.S. nationals, and SIV applicants. Since the fall of Kabul on August 15, the military presence at Kabul International Airport was expanded to nearly 6,000 troops, and the U.S. military took control over the airport's air traffic control. The military operation has successfully evacuated thousands of people from the country, with the Department of Defense activating the Civil Reserve Air Fleet on August 22 to augment military flights and transport Afghans arriving at U.S. bases in Bahrain, Qatar, and the United Arab Emirates.

Operation Allies Refuge, a U.S. military operation aimed at evacuating at-risk Afghan civilians including interpreters, U.S. embassy workers, and other Special Immigrant Visa (SIV) applicants, is ongoing amid the U.S. military withdrawal from Afghanistan. On August 12, the Biden administration announced that 3,000 U.S. troops would be deployed to secure the evacuation at the Kabul International Airport. As of August 22, the Department of Defense has activated the Civil Reserve Air Fleet for the third time, sending 18 planes to assist in the evacuation of American citizens. The Pentagon estimates they have evacuated about 12,700 Afghans so far. However, the operation was marred by casualties, including eight fatalities at the Kabul International Airport, with two people falling to their deaths from the sky while clinging to the landing gear of a departing C-17 cargo plane. Two armed men who fired into a crowd were also killed by U.S. troops.

Operation Allies Refuge is a United States military operation currently ongoing in Afghanistan that focuses on the evacuation of at-risk Afghan civilians, including interpreters, embassy employees, and potential Special Immigrant Visa applicants. The operation began in July 2021 and was officially named by the Biden administration. Since then, the operation has been focused on the Kabul International Airport, where US military personnel helps with evacuation efforts of US citizens, permanent residents, and refugees. The operation has seen the successful evacuation of thousands of people from the country, including 24 people evacuated by Fox News, including three Afghan nationals who assisted with the network's coverage of the war. The operation has also been marred by casualties, including multiple deaths at the Kabul International Airport as thousands of people attempted to board departing planes. Despite the challenges and dangers, Operation Allies Refuge remains ongoing in its mission to evacuate at-risk Afghans from the country.

The ongoing United States military operation, Operation Allies Refuge, which aims to airlift selected at-risk Afghan civilians, has seen updates. U.S. personnel have been assisting NATO and regional allies in their respective evacuation efforts at Kabul International Airport. On August 12, following the deterioration of the situation in Afghanistan, the Biden administration announced that 3,000 U.S. troops would be deployed to secure the evacuation of embassy personnel, U.S. nationals, and SIV applicants. As of August 22, nearly 20,000 SIV holders and applicants still remain in the process of being relocated. The Civil Reserve Air Fleet has been activated to assist in the evacuation, and commercial airline pilots and crews will help transport thousands of Afghans to U.S. bases in the Middle East. President Joe Biden recently announced that American troops may remain in Afghanistan beyond the August 31 deadline and revealed that 11,000 people were evacuated from the country over the past 36 hours. The operation's casualties have been devastating, with at least eight people killed at Kabul International Airport, including two who fell to their deaths after clinging to the landing gear of a departing C-17 cargo plane, and three killed after being run over while clinging to the side of an Air Force jet. Two armed men who fired into a crowd were killed by U.S. troops.

The Panjshir conflict, which began on 17 August 2021 following the Fall of Kabul, is an ongoing conflict between the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan, including the Panjshir resistance led by Ahmad Massoud and self-proclaimed acting president Amrullah Saleh, and the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan controlled by the Taliban. The Panjshir Valley, largely contiguous with Panjshir Province, is currently the only region out of the Taliban's control. The Panjshir resistance, consisting of anti-Taliban forces who have regrouped in the valley, has approximately 9,000 fighters and several armoured humvees at its disposal, according to Massoud. The population of the Panjshir valley consists mainly of ethnic Tajik people, and the valley is well known for its natural defences. Amid attempts to negotiate an end to the political impasse, Massoud has insisted that the Panjshir Valley will not be surrendered to the Taliban and that war is "unavoidable" if the Taliban refuse dialogue on the formation of a comprehensive government. The USA and Western forces have been lowly supportive of the Panjshir resistance due to ongoing evacuation of Kabul depending fully on the Taliban's benevolence.

Operation Allies Refuge, the United States military operation to evacuate at-risk Afghan civilians, including interpreters and U.S. embassy employees, continues alongside the ongoing American military withdrawal from Afghanistan. On August 22, President Joe Biden announced that American troops may remain in Afghanistan past the August 31 deadline while also reporting that 11,000 people have been evacuated in the past 36 hours. However, on the same day, a security guard was killed and three others were wounded in a gunfight between an unknown gunman and Afghan forces at the north gate of Kabul airport, in which German and American forces were also involved. The operation has seen the previous evacuation of 12,700 people from the country, including 2,500 Americans, with the activation of the Civil Reserve Air Fleet to assist in the evacuation. However, casualties have also been recorded, with at least eight people killed at the Kabul International Airport in the past few weeks, including individuals who fell from departing cargo planes and were run over by U.S. troops.

The 2021 Niger attacks continue to wreak havoc as militants target civilians and soldiers in various regions of the country. The death toll has risen to over 500 people with more than 100 others injured. The past few months have seen attacks every month, and the attacks are carried out with increasing frequency. The January attack and March 21 attack have been the deadliest against civilians in the country, marking the first time that over 100 civilians were killed in a single incident. The recent attack on a military post in Diffa saw Boko Haram militants killing 16 soldiers and wounding nine others, while around 50 insurgents were killed in the ensuing gun battle. These attacks signal the growing unrest in Niger, and the authorities are working to curb the violence and ensure the safety of its citizens.

On 26 August 2021, a devastating suicide bombing occurred at an entrance of Hamid Karzai International Airport in Kabul, Afghanistan, killing at least 90 Afghan civilians and 13 American servicemembers, leaving more than 150 others wounded. The attack was claimed by the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant – Khorasan Province (ISIL-KP), who have recently threatened the airport. The attack occurred amidst the ongoing evacuation efforts of foreign nationals and Afghans as the Taliban takes control of Afghanistan. After the attack, the airport was closed, and Western countries including the United States, United Kingdom, and Australia urged their citizens to avoid the airport due to continued security threats. The Taliban and international leaders have condemned the attack. The incident marks one of the deadliest attacks against the United States in Afghanistan since 2011.

Following the fall of Kabul to the Taliban in August 2021, there have been several drone strikes in Afghanistan. The most recent strike, carried out by the United States, targeted two members of the Islamic State group in Nangarhar province. The strike also wounded a third member, and reports suggest that one of those killed was planning more attacks in Kabul. The MQ-9 Reaper drone was used to carry out the strike, and officials have stated that guided munitions were used to minimize civilian casualties. While the Taliban have condemned the strikes, the US has stated that they are necessary to prevent further attacks on American troops and citizens in Afghanistan.

On August 26, 2021, a suicide bombing at Hamid Karzai International Airport in Kabul, Afghanistan led to the death of at least 182 people, including 13 members of the United States military and 28 Taliban members. The bomber was later identified as Abdul Rahman al-Logari, a member of the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant – Khorasan Province (ISIL-KP), which claimed responsibility for the attack. The attack occurred during a chaotic evacuation of Afghanistan after the Taliban assumed control of the country in mid-August, and concerns about security at the airport were high due to reports of increased activity by ISIL-KP. On August 27, the United States launched an airstrike against an ISIL-KP member in Nangarhar Province, killing two members and wounding a third, including a planner in Kabul. The Taliban and ISIL-KP, although both jihadist groups, have fought each other. The Taliban condemned the attack and vowed to take measures to capture ISIL-KP leader Shahab al-Muhajir. Numerous countries expressed condemnation of the attack and support for those affected, including the United States, United Kingdom, and United Nations. Civilians claimed that the attack strengthened their resolve to evacuate, and many continue to be evacuated despite the tragedy.

On August 15, 2021, the Taliban returned to power in Afghanistan and proclaimed intentions to re-establish the Islamic Emirate. Despite this, the United States does not officially recognize the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan as a government, stating they could only recognize a government that respected basic rights. On August 27, the Islamic Emirate appointed Khalil Haqqani, a designated terrorist and former Soviet-Afghan War and war on terror veteran, as head of security in Kabul. The same day, the US launched an airstrike killing two "high-profiled" ISIS targets and injuring a third following the 2021 Kabul airport attack. The Taliban condemned the attack as a "clear attack on Afghan territory." In response to the attack, the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan stated their commitment to pursue and capture ISIS-K leader Shahab al-Muhajir, who claimed responsibility for the airport attack.

Following the Taliban's takeover of Afghanistan and their announcement of the re-establishment of the Islamic Emirate, the country has witnessed multiple drone strikes. The most recent incident involves a U.S. airstrike that targeted a vehicle driven by an aid worker for U.S.-based Nutrition and Education International, resulting in the deaths of at least 10 people, including seven children. Some of those killed held visas allowing them entry into the United States and were former employees of international organizations. The majority of casualties were local residents. This follows an earlier U.S. drone strike that killed two high-profile members of the IS-K group. While the Taliban has condemned the drone strikes, the increasing number of civilian casualties is a growing concern.

The Panjshir conflict has continued between the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan and the Taliban-controlled Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan, with the Panjshir Valley being the last remaining area outside of Taliban control. The National Resistance Front of Afghanistan, led by Amrullah Saleh and Ahmad Massoud, has engaged in ongoing clashes with the Taliban, with their fighters reportedly killing eight Taliban members in recent battles. Despite the deployment of a large number of Taliban forces near the valley, negotiations are currently taking place in an attempt to resolve the conflict peacefully. The international community has yet to provide significant support for the resistance, with the US and other countries focused on evacuating their citizens from Kabul and seeking cooperation from the Taliban.

The Panjshir conflict continues as the Taliban has entered the Panjshir Valley and clashed with National Resistance Front of Afghanistan forces led by Ahmad Massoud. Both sides report heavy casualties and the Taliban claims to have gained some territory. The former Islamic Republic of Afghanistan, including the National Resistance Front, had de facto control over the valley, which is largely contiguous with Panjshir Province and is known for its natural defences. The Panjshir Valley has never fallen to foreign invaders, including the Soviet Union in the 1980s and the Taliban during the civil war of the 1990s. The population of the Panjshir Valley consists primarily of ethnic Tajik people, while the majority of the Taliban are Pashtuns. The conflict began on August 17, 2021, following the Fall of Kabul and Amrullah Saleh assuming the Afghan presidency and declaring the resistance. The Taliban and resistance forces declared a ceasefire ten days later, but talks broke down on September 1, 2021, leading to resumed fighting. As of now, the international community has not provided public support for either side in the conflict.

Operation Allies Refuge was a United States military operation to airlift at-risk Afghan civilians, particularly interpreters, U.S. embassy employees, and Special Immigrant Visa (SIV) applicants. The operation was concurrent with the larger American military withdrawal from Afghanistan and the evacuation of all eligible foreigners and vulnerable Afghans. Following the fall of Kabul, Operation Allies Refuge became concurrent with a new effort to airlift all SIV applicants, embassy personnel, American nationals, and eligible Afghans seeking to flee the country. On September 7th, White House Chief of Staff Ron Klain reported that around 100 Americans remain in Afghanistan following the August 31 withdrawal deadline, and the Biden administration will still attempt to rescue them. The operation led to the evacuation of at least 120,000 people, including roughly 6,000 American citizens and 7,000 SIV applicants, with thousands more still seeking evacuation. However, the operation was marked by tragedy, as at least 183 people, including thirteen U.S. service members, were killed in a suicide bombing at Kabul's airport on August 26th.

On September 7, a 7.0 magnitude earthquake hit just outside of Acapulco, Guerrero, Mexico, leaving over 1.6 million without power and resulting in at least one death. The earthquake occurred on the anniversary of the 2017 Chiapas earthquake and was a thrust faulting event located on or near the subduction zone boundary of the Caribbean Plate and Cocos Plate. The rupture size, as measured by the U.S. Geological Survey, was 40x20 km, and the earthquake took place at the southern extent of the Guerrero Gap, a seismic gap that could generate an 8.0 magnitude earthquake. Buildings in Acapulco were damaged, and there were reports of gas leaks and a small tsunami, measuring 1.2 feet in Acapulco. Mayor Adela Roman urged residents to remain calm while the situation was being assessed.

Operation Allies Refuge was a U.S. military operation that aimed to airlift at-risk Afghan civilians, interpreters, and U.S. embassy employees, among others, from Afghanistan. It coincided with the larger American military withdrawal from the country and was in response to the Taliban's resurgence. On August 15, following the fall of Kabul, the operation became concurrent with efforts to evacuate all eligible foreigners, American nationals, and vulnerable Afghans. The Kabul airlift was marked by several deadly incidents, including the suicide bombing attack on August 26 that killed at least 182 people, including 13 U.S. service members. As of September 5, around 100 Americans remain in Afghanistan, with the Biden administration pledging to find ways to rescue them. On September 7, U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken announced that 21 Americans have been evacuated from Afghanistan.

Since January 2001, the U.S. government has conducted numerous drone strikes in Afghanistan, leading to at least 13,074 airstrikes and the deaths of at least 4,138 people, including 310 civilians and 73 children. During the presidency of Donald Trump, the number of drone strikes increased at a rate of four to five times compared to the previous administration of Barack Obama. However, one of the latest drone strikes on August 29, which was conducted by the U.S. military near Kabul International Airport, resulted in the deaths of 10 civilians rather than ISIL-K militants as initially reported. Marine Corps General Kenneth F. McKenzie Jr. acknowledged the error, bringing further criticism to the U.S. government for the number of civilian casualties resulting from drone strikes. Amnesty International USA has also questioned the legality of these attacks.

On September 18, 2021, a rally was held near the United States Capitol to show support for those arrested for their roles in the January 6 Capitol riot. The rally, titled "Justice for J6" and organized by Look Ahead America, was attended by a small crowd of around 400 to 450 people. Security concerns led to the restoration of the Capitol's protective fencing and the closure of multiple congressional offices. At least four participants were arrested, with one found to be in possession of a knife and another in possession of a gun. The rally received criticism from Former President Donald Trump, who called it a "setup," and Republicans distanced themselves from the demonstration. Despite law enforcement warnings of potential violence, the rally remained relatively peaceful.

On 19 September 2021, a suspected mass murder took place at a residential property on Chandos Crescent in Killamarsh, Derbyshire, resulting in the deaths of three children and one adult. On 22 September, the Derbyshire Constabulary charged a 31-year-old man named Damien Bendall from Killamarsh with four counts of murder in connection with the incident. The victims were identified as siblings Lacey Bennett and John Paul Bennett, their mother Terri Harris, and Lacey's friend Connie Gent. Killamarsh, a former coal mining town in northern Derbyshire, has become an outer suburb of Sheffield, located just across the border from South Yorkshire. The criminal investigation is ongoing.

On September 25, 2021, an Amtrak passenger train derailed outside the town of Joplin, Montana, killing at least three people and injuring at least 50 others. The train was carrying 147 passengers and 13 crew members at the time of the accident. The westbound train was traveling through the region when it derailed. The survivors were taken to nearby hospitals for medical treatment. The cause of the derailment is still being investigated, and the railway line has been closed for the time being.

On 2 October 2021, Qatar made history by holding its first-ever legislative elections, where 30 members of the Consultative Assembly were elected by the public. The initial plans to hold the election in the latter half of 2013 were continuously postponed until Emir Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani announced its official date in November 2020. A total of 284 candidates ran as independents, with 29 women contesting the election. Candidates were required to be at least thirty years old and of Qatari origin, with the thirty members being elected through single-member constituencies and first-past-the-post voting. Voters aged 18 and above participated in the election, with the remaining 15 seats appointed by the Emir according to the constitution. Political parties are still banned, so all candidates ran as independents. Nonetheless, these elections remain a landmark event for a country that had never before seen a democratic vote.

On October 3, 2021, tragedy struck when a Pilatus PC-12 plane crashed into an empty building in San Donato Milanese, Lombardy, Italy, resulting in the deaths of all eight individuals aboard. This devastating accident shook the world as it claimed the lives of these travelers. May they rest in peace, and may we never forget the lessons learned from such a tragedy.

The Pandora Papers, announced by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists (ICIJ) on October 2, 2021, are 11.9 million leaked documents that expose hidden wealth, tax evasion and money laundering among 330 politicians, including 35 national leaders, and numerous celebrities worldwide. With over 130 billionaires and 29,000 beneficiaries among 27,000 companies, the leaked documents make it the largest offshore data leak in history, surpassing the Panama Papers by nearly half a million documents. The first leaks on October 3, 2021, revealed over 100 billionaires, 30 current and former leaders, and 300 public officials named. Furthermore, the papers disclosed Tony Blair's purchase of a £6.45million property in London by utilizing Romanstone International Limited, a British Virgin Islands company, saving him £312,000 in Stamp Duty, although it was not illegal.

The Pandora Papers, one of the largest offshore data leaks in history, have been published by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists. The 11.9 million leaked documents comprising 2.9 terabytes of data expose hidden wealth, tax evasion, and money laundering practices among 330 politicians, including 35 national leaders, 130 billionaires, and numerous celebrities worldwide, totaling 29,000 beneficiaries among 27,000 companies. This surpasses the Panama Papers by nearly half a million documents. The ICIJ worked with journalists in 117 countries, and prominent names include King Abdullah II of Jordan, former British Prime Minister Tony Blair, and Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta. The documents show that up to an estimated US$32 trillion may be hidden from being taxed. The ICIJ is not identifying the source for the documents.

On October 4, 2021, Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp, and Oculus experienced a widespread outage that lasted several hours, from 15:39 UTC. The cause of the outage was speculated to be a BGP update from Facebook, according to some experts. As a result, users around the world were unable to access these social media platforms and struggled to maintain communication during the downtime. Other social media platforms such as Twitter also reported an increase in activity as users looked for alternative means of communication. The outage serves as a reminder of the increasing dependence on social media platforms and the need for robust backup plans in the event of such disruptions.

A powerful earthquake struck Harnai, Balochistan, Pakistan, on 7 October 2021, killing at least 24 people and injuring around 200 others. The 5.9 magnitude quake occurred near the anniversary of the devastating 2005 Kashmir earthquake, which claimed the lives of 87,000 people. The country sits on the boundary of the Indian Plate and Eurasian Plate, with thrust faulting in the Hindu Kush and Himalaya regions being the direct result of their interactions. The latest quake, caused by a thrust fault under the Sulaiman Mountains and Central Brāhui Range, collapsed many homes in Harnai where residents were asleep. The Provincial Disaster Management Authority (PDMA) has reported severe damage to properties and infrastructure in Harnai District and Shahrag area, as well as in the cities of Sibi and Quetta. The Pakistan Army has dispatched troops to aid in the rescue and relief operations, with medical personnel, response workers, and officials working together to coordinate efforts to find survivors among the wreckage.

On October 13, 2021, tragedy struck in Kongsberg, Norway, as a man using a bow and arrow killed five people and injured two others. The attack happened on the streets of Kongsberg in Viken, Norway, and the perpetrator has since been taken into custody. The attacker targeted people at several locations in the town before being arrested. This incident has left the residents of Kongsberg shaken, as they try to come to grips with this senseless act of violence. Our heartfelt condolences go to the families of the victims during this difficult time.

On 13 October 2021, a man identified as a 37-year-old Norwegian man and convert to Islam with Danish citizenship, opened fire with a bow and arrow at various locations in Kongsberg, Viken, Norway, killing five people and injuring three others. The suspect, who police had previously been concerned about regarding radicalization, was identified as Espen Andersen Bråthen. He was quickly taken into custody after a large police response, including a terrorism investigation by the Norwegian Police Security Service. The attack was the deadliest in Norway since the 2011 attacks committed by Anders Behring Breivik, and police constables were ordered to temporarily carry firearms nationwide in response. The day after the attack, flags were flown at half-mast on all public buildings and candles were lit at Kongsberg Church.

On October 15, 2021, a suicide bombing took place at the Imam Bargah mosque in Kandahar, Afghanistan, during Friday prayers, leaving over 65 people dead and more than 70 others injured. Amaq, the media wing of the Islamic State – Khorasan Province, claimed responsibility for the attack. This incident occurred only a week after a bombing at a Shia mosque in Kunduz, claimed by IS-KP, which resulted in the death of at least 50 people. In response to these attacks, the Taliban has expressed that they will increase security measures at Shi'ite mosques to prevent any further violence from IS-KP.

Sir David Amess, a long-serving Conservative Party Member of Parliament for Southend West, was stabbed to death on October 15, 2021, at a constituency surgery in Leigh-on-Sea. The attack took place while Amess was speaking with constituents, and a 25-year-old man was arrested at the scene. Recently, the police have declared it a terrorist attack. Amess was a committed public servant, who held relatively centrist views, notably opposing abortion and campaigning for Brexit, stronger animal welfare protections, and awarding Southend-on-Sea city status. In the wake of the attack, politicians from across the political spectrum, as well as the United Nations, expressed shock and offered condolences. The security of MPs will also be reviewed, while campaigning activities for the Conservative Party have been suspended nationwide until further notice. BBC One also changed its evening schedule out of respect. The attacker's motivations remain unclear as the Counter-Terrorism Command's investigation continues.

In September 2021, a ban on Serbian license plates in Kosovo led to a series of protests by Kosovo Serbs, which included blocking traffic near border crossings. The ban aimed to mirror the former ban on Kosovar license plates in Serbia and would have affected around 9,500 vehicles. On 30 September 2021, an agreement was reached to end the ban starting 4 October 2021, in which both sides agreed to cover national symbols and country codes on license plates with a sticker. The protests ended on 2 October 2021, and a working group is being formed to find a permanent solution. The negotiators from the governments of Kosovo and Serbia will announce their proposals in six months. The license plate issue has led to heightened tensions between the two countries, with Russia condemning Kosovo's actions and the Serbian Armed Forces on heightened combat readiness. International powers have called for de-escalation.

Sir David Amess, a British Conservative Party politician and Member of Parliament (MP) for Southend West, was fatally stabbed multiple times on 15 October 2021 while holding a one-to-one constituency meeting at the Belfairs Methodist Church Hall in Essex. Following the incident, Ali Harbi Ali, a 25-year-old male British citizen, was arrested and later charged with Amess's murder and the preparation of terrorist acts. Ali appeared at Westminster Magistrates' Court and the Old Bailey, and has been remanded to Belmarsh prison. He is set to go on trial on March 7, 2022. Amess was a long-serving politician and known for his socially conservative views, animal welfare advocacy, and support for Brexit. His death prompted tributes from colleagues and members of the public, and led to a by-election to fill his former seat. The safety of MPs during public constituency surgeries has been debated, with politicians calling for increased security measures and a law to prevent online targeting of MPs. Amess's last rites were administered at a service of remembrance by MPs at St Margaret's Church, Westminster, and a campaign to award city status to Southend-on-Sea in his honor was successful.

Solar cycle 25, the current pattern of sunspot activity, began in December 2019 and is expected to continue until approximately 2030. Initial predictions about the strength of this cycle ranged from very weak to strong. However, the Solar Cycle 25 Prediction Panel forecasted that cycle 25 would be similar to the previous cycle, with a weaker than average sunspot activity. Early signs of cycle 25 were observed through polarward reversed polarity sunspots in April 2018 and November 2019, and a recent analysis of December 2019's magnetic regions indicates the brewing of magnetic regions with the underlying orientation of cycle 25 in the solar convection zone. Solar activity started increasing in 2020, with the first C-class solar flares, M-class flares, and an X-class solar flare, the second of the current cycle, which peaked at X1.59. An associated coronal mass ejection may graze Earth on October 30 or 31, potentially causing bright aurorae and satellite communication interference. The number of spotless days by year indicates a decrease in activity in 2021 with only 43 days recorded.

The 2021 G20 summit, held in Rome on 30-31 October, marked the first in-person meeting of Group of Twenty leaders since the pandemic began. Despite ongoing health concerns, most leaders appeared in person, with the exception of Russian President Vladimir Putin and Chinese President Xi Jinping, who appeared via video link. The summit welcomed participating leaders from 20 countries, including Australia, Brazil, Canada, France, Germany, India, Indonesia, Italy, Japan, South Korea, Mexico, Saudi Arabia, South Africa, Turkey, the United Kingdom, and the United States. The summit also welcomed invited guests from Brunei, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, the Netherlands, Rwanda, Singapore, and Spain. During the summit, leaders discussed a range of issues, including global economic recovery, climate change, and pandemic recovery efforts.

The 2021 Salisbury rail crash, which occurred on 31 October, resulted in seventeen people being injured after two trains collided and one was derailed near Salisbury railway station in Wiltshire, England. The incident took place at Fisherton Tunnel close to London Road at approximately 19:00 UTC. The emergency services responded quickly, with the police, fire department, and ambulances attending the scene. The updated information reveals an increase in the number of injuries reported initially from twelve to seventeen.

On Monday, November 1, 2021, a 22-story building in the Ikoyi neighborhood of Lagos, Nigeria collapsed while undergoing construction, resulting in the death of 15 people and several others being trapped. The tragedy, which occurred at approximately 3 p.m. UTC+01:00, has left the nation in mourning as families and loved ones of those affected seek answers and justice. The incident serves as a stark reminder of the importance of safety regulations in the construction industry, prompting investigations into the matter to prevent such tragedies in the future.

On 2 November 2021, a major attack took place at the Daoud Khan Military Hospital in Kabul, Afghanistan. The attack involved a bomb exploding at the hospital's entrance, followed by gunfire and a second explosion. The attack resulted in the deaths of at least 25 individuals and injured over 50 others. The Taliban reported that four of the attackers were killed and one was captured. Although no group claimed responsibility, the Taliban suggested that the attack was carried out by insurgents belonging to the Islamic State – Khorasan Province. This assault marks the latest violence perpetrated by extremist groups in Afghanistan, highlighting the ongoing instability and turmoil in the region.

On 1 November 2021, a 21-story high-rise building, one of the three "360 Degrees Towers" under construction by Fourscore Homes at 44BCD Gerrard Road in Ikoyi, Lagos, Nigeria, collapsed, killing at least 22 people. The building was being constructed higher than authorized, with only 15 floors approved by the Lagos State Building Control Agency. It was also reported that consultancy firm Prowess Engineering Limited had previously withdrawn from the project due to concerns about the building's integrity. The rescue operation by the National Emergency Management Agency in Lagos State is ongoing, with an uncertain number of people still trapped in the rubble. Meanwhile, the Lagos State government has arrested and will prosecute the owner of the building, while the chief architect has been suspended pending investigations.

On November 2, 2021, incumbent New Jersey Governor Phil Murphy won the gubernatorial election for a second term, defeating Republican former state legislator Jack Ciattarelli. This victory made Murphy the first Democrat to be re-elected since Brendan Byrne in 1977. The primaries were held on June 8, 2021, where Murphy won the Democratic nomination unopposed after his two primary challengers were disqualified. Ciattarelli won the Republican nomination, beating four other challengers. The general election featured five candidates, including Libertarian nominee Gregg Mele, Green nominee Madelyn Hoffman, and Socialist Workers nominee Joanne Kuniansky. Despite being unable to participate in any debates sponsored by the New Jersey Election Law Enforcement Commission, third-party candidates did attend a debate for third-party Lieutenant Governor candidates on October 11, 2021, hosted by the New Jersey Globe.

On 1 November 2021, a 21-story luxury residential high-rise tower in Ikoyi, Lagos, Nigeria, called the "360 Degrees Towers", collapsed, killing at least 36 people. The tower was being constructed by Fourscore Homes, a United Kingdom-registered company headed by an experienced Nigerian developer Femi Osibona. In February 2020, consultancy firm Prowess Engineering Limited withdrew from the project over concerns regarding the integrity of that building. The Lagos State Building Control Agency had approved only 15 floors, but 21 had been built. A rescue effort by the National Emergency Management Agency in Lagos State (NEMA) and other responders was conducted, and as of 3 November no new survivors have been found. The state government suspended the chief architect, and an investigation through an independent panel has been allotted 30 days to disclose findings.

UPDATE: On November 5, 2021, a horrific incident occurred in Freetown, Sierra Leone, where an oil tanker collided with a truck, resulting in an explosion that left at least 99 people dead and over 100 injured. This tragedy occurred in the suburb of Wellington near Choithram Supermarket, where fuel spilled before igniting, causing a deadly fire. Some reports are stating that a bus was fully burnt, and nearby shops and markets caught on fire, leading to massive destruction. Freetown is no stranger to disasters as it has experienced several in the past, such as a fire in March that saw around 80 people injured and over 5,000 displaced, and mudslides in 2017 that took over 1,000 lives. While rescue efforts have ended, many of the seriously injured people are not expected to survive, and hospitals in the area are facing stretched resources. President Julius Maada Bio and Vice President Mohamed Juldeh Jalloh offered their condolences and promised support to victims' families.

On November 5, 2021, a tragic incident occurred during the Astroworld Music Festival in Houston, Texas, where eight people lost their lives in a stampede and crowd crush while hundreds more were injured. The cause of death and injuries are still under investigation. The festival was operated by rapper Travis Scott and had approximately 50,000 attendees. Earlier on the day of the festival, fans surged towards the perimeter, knocking over metal detectors in an attempt to get in. During Scott's performance that night, the crowd began to compress towards the stage, causing a crush before additional panic and chaos ensued. Scott and his crew paused when they noticed attendees in distress near the stage, but they resumed the performance after a short break. This incident has caused the cancellation of the second night of the festival and the setting up of a reunification center for families searching for their loved ones. Scott has pledged to support the investigation and help heal the Houston community, while Kylie Jenner's Instagram posts of the crowd have been criticized.

The United Arab Emirates' relationship with Syria has been rekindled as Emirati Foreign Minister Abdullah bin Zayed Al Nahyan met with Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, marking the first time the two nations engage in diplomatic talks since the Syrian Civil War began a decade ago. Amid the meeting, the leaders discussed collaborative efforts aimed at boosting cooperation across different sectors that are of common interest to both countries. Despite the civil conflict that has brought devastation to Syria, both nations maintain embassies in each other's respective capitals and share cultural bonds as part of their Middle Eastern heritage.

UPDATE:

On 5 November 2021, a fuel tanker collision and explosion at a busy junction in Sierra Leone's capital and largest city, Freetown, resulted in a towering inferno which killed at least 115 people and injured over 100 others. The collision occurred at the Wellington area, Freetown's main industrial district, when a lorry carrying granite crashed into a petrol tanker at an intersection outside Choithram Supermarket, causing petrol to spill and bystanders attempting to collect it in containers. The ignition of the petrol created a huge fireball that engulfed vehicles in traffic, including a bus that was burned with no survivors. Nearby shops and markets also caught fire as fuel spilled onto the streets. Local media outlets broadcast footage of charred bodies surrounding the tanker. Mayor Yvonne Aki-Sawyerr stated that people who gathered at the lorry, scooped the leaking fuel in containers and placed them in close proximity to the collision scene exacerbated the damage. Footage showed the devastating aftermath of the explosion and the overwhelming medical services. The director of the National Disaster Management Agency (NDMA), Mohamed Lamrane Bah, said that the rescue efforts ended on 6 November, leaving many people injured, and that about 30 severely burned victims are not expected to survive. The president and vice president offered condolences and promised support to the victims' families, while the hospital services were stretched. This event is a similar occurrence of high-casualty fuel tanker explosions that happened in sub-Saharan Africa, such as the 2018 Mbuba and 2019 Morogoro disasters, and highlights the need for stricter safety regulations.

Israel's "Give a Shoulder" COVID-19 vaccination program has been highly successful, with about 64 percent of eligible Israelis having received at least one dose and 60 percent receiving two doses, making Israel one of the world leaders in vaccination rates per capita. The program was made possible through coordinated efforts and the centralized government system's ability to utilize personal information for Israeli patients. Recently, Israel's pandemic advisory board approved the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine's usage for children between the ages of 5 and 11 years old. However, the country faced distribution issues early on, with supply problems and vaccine hesitancy among its population, with 12% of its population, such as Haredi Jews, being less likely to be vaccinated. Additionally, the distribution of vaccines to Palestinians has not been as thorough as to Israeli citizens, with some officials urging the government to provide vaccinations to all Palestinians.

On 14 November 2021 at approximately 10:59 am GMT, a terrorist incident occurred outside the Liverpool Women's Hospital in Liverpool, England, as an improvised explosive device detonated inside a taxi, killing the passenger who was of Middle Eastern origin and injuring the driver, who has since been released. The event caused a lockdown in the area, with armed police responding and making three arrests, including one on Boaler Street, which is within walking distance of the hospital. Yesterday, the police declared the incident as a terrorist attack, and Mayor Joanne Anderson revealed that the driver locked the bomber inside the vehicle after noticing that the bomber was wearing an explosive device. The explosives went off a few moments later, killing the bomber and causing significant damage to the taxi. MI5 is supporting the local police in the investigation, and the UK terror threat level has been raised from substantial to severe. The event made international news, and the motives behind the suicide attack are still unknown.

Tonga held its general elections on 18 November 2021 to elect 17 of the 26 seats in the Legislative Assembly. Following the 2017 general election, Pohiva, the then Prime Minister, won a landslide victory for the Democratic Party of the Friendly Islands. However, after his death in September 2019, Pohiva Tu'i'onetoa was elected as the new Prime Minister with the support of nobles, independent MPs, and former members of the DPFI. In December 2020, the Democratic Party leader submitted a motion of no-confidence in Prime Minister Tu'i'onetoa, but it was rejected by the Legislative Assembly in January 2021. Campaigning for the 2021 elections took place amid a week-long lockdown due to a COVID-19 case, but it did not delay the election process.

UPDATED VERSION:
On November 23, at approximately 02:00 local time, a tragic bus accident occurred on a motorway near the village of Bosnek, south-west of Sofia in Bulgaria. The bus, carrying Macedonian tourists who were returning from Istanbul, crashed and caught fire, resulting in the death of 46 individuals and leaving seven others injured. The accident occurred in the Pernik Province of Bulgaria and has left countless families devastated.

The 2021 Solomon Islands unrest, which began on 24 November 2021, continues with violent riots and protests occurring in the country, particularly in Malaita Province. The Australian government has deployed Australian Federal Police and Australian Defence Force personnel to support the Solomon Islands Police Force and maintain order, following a request from Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare under the Australia-Solomon Islands Bilateral Security Treaty. The unrest turned violent on 24 November 2021, resulting in buildings being burnt down and police firing tear gas at protesters. The rioting and looting continue in the Chinatown suburb of Honiara, leading to a nighttime curfew beginning at 7:00 p.m. local time. The protests originated from the central government's decision in 2019 to establish relations with the mainland People's Republic of China, to which Malaita Province did not agree, as they continued to receive support from Taiwan and the United States. Despite condemnations from domestic and international leaders, the Prime Minister, Manasseh Sogavare, has resisted calls to step down and accused the rioters of being "politically motivated" and backed by "foreign powers."

The 2021-2022 European windstorm season marks the seventh occurrence of seasonal European windstorm naming in Europe. Participating meteorological agencies include those from the United Kingdom, Ireland, the Netherlands, France, Spain, Portugal, Belgium, Luxembourg, Greece, Israel, Cyprus, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Montenegro, North Macedonia, and Malta. Storm names were released on September 1, 2021, and any storms occurring until August 31, 2022, will be included in this season. The recent Storm Arwen, named by the Met Office on November 25, 2021, caused three deaths in the United Kingdom, widespread damage, and travel disruptions in Scotland and North East England with many people losing power.

On November 30, 2021, a 15-year-old student opened fire on his classmates at Oxford High School in Oxford Township, Michigan, killing four students and injuring seven others. The shooter reportedly used a semiautomatic handgun for the shooting, and was taken into custody after giving himself up to police. The incident occurred despite earlier threats of a mass shooting that had been reported to school administrators. The tragedy prompted expressions of condolences from President Joe Biden and other officials, and reignited calls for stricter gun control laws to address the ongoing public health crisis of gun violence in the United States.

The Semeru volcano on the Indonesian island of Java erupted on December 4, 2021, resulting in one death and 41 injuries. Semeru is one of the most active volcanoes in Indonesia and has been erupting since 2014. The volcano erupted again, ejecting a cloud of volcanic ash into the air, which caused power outages, blackouts, and affected at least 30,253 people in the Malang and Lumajang regions. Lahars destroyed at least 30 homes in the Pronojiwo District of East Java, and an estimated 300 families were evacuated. The authorities warned residents to keep their distance from the main summit crater as there is a risk of large pyroclastic flows, and individuals are prohibited from approaching 1 km or closer to the crater. Indonesian President Joko Widodo led the BNPB in post-eruption recovery efforts on December 5, while the Governor of East Java relocated her office to the Lumajang Regency to aid in the evacuation process of residents in the danger zone.

On December 4, 2021, thirteen miners returning home from work in Nagaland were mistakenly shot by Indian soldiers of the Assam Rifles who believed them to be militants. This resulted in the death of thirteen people, including a soldier, and subsequent violence. The incident sparked public outrage, and many called for the repeal of the Armed Forces Special Powers Act (AFSPA). The Indian army claimed that the killing was a case of mistaken identity resulting from an intelligence failure. A Special Investigation Team was formed to probe the incident, and the National Human Rights Commission of India sent notices to the Central and State governments. The incident led to protests, vandalism, and the suspension of all activities at the Hornbill Festival, as well as a six-hour shutdown called by the Naga Students' Federation.

As of the latest update, the United Kingdom has reported a record-breaking 78,610 new cases of COVID-19 within the past 24 hours, signaling a surge in infections driven by the highly contagious Omicron variant. This surge has prompted the UK government to implement additional restrictions and measures to try and contain the spread of the virus. The country's vaccination program has also been ramped up further in an effort to increase protection against the new Omicron variant. Despite high case numbers, the mortality rate has not risen as sharply as previous waves thanks to high vaccination rates.

The House of Commons constituency of North Shropshire, located in the West Midlands, held a by-election on 16 December 2021 triggered by the resignation of Conservative MP Owen Paterson on 4 November 2021. In a surprising upset, Helen Morgan, the Liberal Democrat candidate, won the election with a significant 34.1% swing, making it the first time the Conservative Party has lost the seat since the constituency's creation. North Shropshire is the third-largest constituency in the West Midlands by area and includes five small towns. The constituency saw 14 candidates run in the by-election, including those from minor parties as well as independent candidates. The by-election was held following the resignation of Owen Paterson, who was found to have breached paid advocacy rules and was facing a suspension from Parliament.

On 20 December 2021, the Francia, a 12-meter-long wooden cargo ship carrying 130 passengers, sank off the northeast coast of Madagascar after its engine room flooded due to a hole in its hull, leaving it vulnerable to wave action. Among the 138 people onboard, at least 85 lost their lives. On 23 December, authorities discovered 24 more bodies, bringing the total death toll to 85. The Francia had illegally taken on passengers for a journey from Antanambe, an unofficial port, to Soanierana Ivongo, a distance of about 100 kilometers. Madagascan police minister Serge Gelle and Chief Warrant Officer Jimmy Laitsara survived after the helicopter they were riding in crashed as it approached the site of the wreck. Despite being spotted by a fisherman, Gelle's swim to safety took 12 hours as he used a helicopter seat as a flotation device. An investigation into the sinking started, and the Madagascan Maritime and Port Agency announced that the confirmed death toll had increased to 85, with three persons missing. The graveyard of Soanierana-Ivongo was too small to accommodate all the bodies recovered, so some were sent to nearby villages for burial. Madagascan president Andry Rajoelina paid tribute to the victims of the shipwreck and helicopter crash, and authorities continued to search for the remaining missing passengers.

South Australia has seen a surge in COVID-19 cases, with a record 744 new cases reported in the past 24 hours, bringing the total number of confirmed cases in the state to 4,324. The outbreak has prompted the introduction of strict lockdown measures, including a ban on outdoor exercise and limits on leaving the home to buy essential items. The SA government has also introduced a vaccine mandate for certain industries, including healthcare, aged care, and disability care, with fines for non-compliance. With the situation evolving rapidly, residents are being urged to stay vigilant and adhere to public health guidelines in order to keep themselves and their communities safe.

Since the record rainfall on 24 December 2021, the northeastern Brazilian state of Bahia has continued to experience severe flooding, resulting in the deaths of at least 18 people, with 280 injured and more than 35,000 displaced. The state capital Salvador alone received over 250 millimetres (9.8 inches) of rain on 24 December, five times its historic average. As a result, 72 municipalities in Bahia have declared a state of emergency, and the state and Brazilian federal governments, along with other state governments, have collaborated on a joint rescue operation for those affected. Furthermore, two dams have collapsed in Jussiape and Itambe since the flooding began. These floods come on the heels of severe flooding in southern Bahia earlier in December caused by Subtropical Storm Ubá.

Iran's "soft war" military strategy includes cyberwarfare, in which they have emerged as a significant player in recent years. Since 2010, "The Cyber Defense Command" has been operating under Iran's "Passive Civil Defense Organization," which is a subdivision of the Joint Staff of the Iranian Armed Forces. A 2014 report by the Institute for National Security Studies describes Iran as "one of the most active players in the international cyber arena" and a Revolutionary Guards general claimed in 2013 that Iran has "the 4th biggest cyber power among the world's cyber armies." In 2021, a cybersecurity company reported that Iran is running two surveillance operations targeting over 1,000 dissidents. Iran's national internet includes a cyber defense system to engage attackers. In 2010, Iran was the victim of a cyber-attack when its nuclear facility in Natanz was infiltrated by the Stuxnet worm, which reportedly set back Tehran's atomic program by at least two years. Recently, suspected Iranian hackers hacked Israel's Jerusalem Post newspaper, replaced the website's content with a threat targeting the Shimon Peres Negev Nuclear Research Center, and made an apparent reference to Qasem Soleimani's assassination exactly two years earlier in Baghdad, Iraq.

On January 9, 2022, a devastating fire broke out in a 19-story apartment building located in the Belmont neighborhood of the Bronx, New York City. According to the latest reports, the fire has claimed seventeen lives and left 44 others injured. This tragic incident is now being considered one of the worst fires in New York City's history. The cause of the fire is still under investigation by the authorities.

The 2021-2022 Russo-Ukrainian crisis, an ongoing military and diplomatic conflict between Russia and Ukraine that began in late October 2021, has escalated further with the recent arrest of an alleged Russian intelligence agent by Ukrainian authorities. The agent is accused of attempting to recruit others to launch attacks in the port city of Odessa. This development comes amid reports of heightened military activity near the Ukrainian borders and harsh statements from both Kyiv and Moscow, as negotiations on all existing platforms remain deadlocked. In the meantime, the US and Russia have announced bilateral talks in Geneva on 10 January 2022, to discuss concerns about their respective military activity and to confront rising tensions over Ukraine, and Russia is set to hold talks with NATO in Brussels on 12 January 2022.

The ongoing Russo-Ukrainian crisis continues to escalate with talks between NATO and Russia reaching a breaking point, leading to grim warnings from Poland of a potential war. The crisis began due to the first combat use of the Ukrainian Bayraktar TB2 UAV against the DPR formations in October 2021, causing international tension between Russia, Ukraine, the US, NATO, the European Union and the Commonwealth of Independent States. Ukrainian intelligence had warned of the deployment of additional Russian troops to the borders, and on 9 December, Russia accused Ukraine of moving heavy artillery towards the separatists, pushing the situation towards a forced settlement of the Donbass conflict. At this time, concerns regarding possible military action continue to loom as the Ukrainian Government announces the arrest of an alleged Russian military intelligence agent who was attempting to recruit others to conduct attacks, and Poland warns of the possibility of war.

The 2022 Australian Open, the 110th edition of the tournament, will be held at Melbourne Park in Melbourne, Victoria, Australia from 17–30 January 2022. The International Tennis Federation (ITF) oversees the tournament, which is part of the 2022 ATP Tour and the 2022 WTA Tour calendars under the Grand Slam category. Men's and women's singles and doubles and mixed doubles events are featured. There are also singles and doubles events for both boys and girls, as well as singles, doubles, and quad events for men's and women's wheelchair tennis players as part of the NEC tour under the Grand Slam category. The tournament, played on hard courts, includes 25 courts, including five main tennis arenas, with Rod Laver Arena, John Cain Arena, Margaret Court Arena, 1573 Arena, and debutant Kia Arena. Defending champions are Novak Djokovic and Naomi Osaka in Men's Singles and Women's Singles, respectively. However, following much controversy, it has been reported that the Minister for Immigration and Citizenship, Alex Hawke, has used his ministerial powers under the Migration Act 1958 to cancel Novak Djokovic's visa on "health and good order grounds."

On January 15, 2022, an armed man claiming to be the brother of Pakistani Al-Qaeda suspect Aafia Siddiqui entered Congregation Beth Israel, a Jewish synagogue in Colleyville, Texas and took multiple congregants hostage during a bar mitzvah. The assailant posed as a homeless man in need of shelter to enter the synagogue. After more than 12 hours of negotiations, the hostage taker was shot and killed by police. One hostage was released safely earlier in the day. Law enforcement has not identified the assailant, who demanded the release of Aafia Siddiqui as part of his negotiations. Siddiqui's lawyer stated that she had no involvement with the hostage crisis and condemned the action. Israeli Prime Minister Naftali Bennett and the Alternate Prime Minister of Israel, Yair Lapid, were closely monitoring the situation and the Israeli Consulate General was in contact with American law enforcement.

On 15 January 2022, a massive eruption of Hunga Tonga, a volcanic island in Tonga in the Pacific Ocean, caused widespread tsunamis in Tonga, Fiji, American Samoa, and other countries, triggering tsunami warnings in Fiji, Samoa, Vanuatu, New Zealand, Australia, Japan, the United States, Canada, Chile, and Ecuador. The eruption was preceded by a smaller eruption on 20 December 2021, and the size of the island had increased on satellite imagery by 25 December, before being declared dormant on 11 January 2022. The subsequent eruption produced a wide column of ash, sent large amounts of volcanic material into the stratosphere, and had the potential to cause a temporary climate effect. The 15 January tsunami struck the Tongan capital Nukuʻalofa, causing damage and evacuations, and also affected other Pacific countries, with minor tsunamis being recorded as far away as the Gulf of Mexico and the Caribbean. Most recently, two people were killed by a small tsunami in Lambayeque, Peru. Assistance efforts are underway and aid is being discussed by foreign affairs officials in New Zealand.

In an ongoing large-scale attack by the Islamic State, Al-Sina'a prison in Al-Hasakah city was targeted, resulting in the freeing of prisoners and clashes that caused the death of 67 people. Previously termed by the SOHR as the largest attack by the Islamic State since losing its key Syrian territory in 2019, the attack began on 20th January when car bombs were launched at the prison and IS ground fighters opened fire with heavy weapons. A riot followed, with prisoners obtaining armoury weaponry and attacking prison staff, effectively occupying the prison and facilitating several escapees. Clashes continued into the following day while the Kurdish Administration of northern Syria received support from the International Coalition, and the SDF announced the arrest of 89 of the prisoners. The prison and surrounding areas remain under dispute.

Singapore's ongoing COVID-19 vaccination campaign is set to extend booster shots to individuals aged 12 to 17 years old starting on March 14th. This announcement follows Singapore's efforts to vaccinate its population, with more than 88% of the population completing their vaccine regimen. Singapore invested over one billion dollars in purchasing promising vaccine candidates from Pfizer BioNTech, Moderna, and CoronaVac. The Expert Committee on COVID-19 Vaccination recommended prioritizing high-risk groups such as frontline healthcare workers and the elderly for vaccination. Singapore became the first Asian country to approve Pfizer-BioNTech's vaccine in December 2020 and started its vaccination campaign on December 30th, 2020. As of September 2021, Singapore has started rolling out booster shots for the senior population above 60 from September 14th, with plans to extend booster shots to individuals above 18 starting December 14th.

On 25 January 2022, the Baloch Liberation Front claimed responsibility for an insurgent attack in Kech District, Balochistan, Pakistan, which claimed the lives of ten Pakistan Army soldiers. The army conducted a clearance operation and reported that one attacker was killed and three others were arrested. The separatist group has not yet explained the motives behind the attack. The militants also seized weapons from the security post during the few-hour long clash, and locals in the area verified that militants, too, suffered multiple casualties.

UPDATED VERSION:
Between January 31—February 1, 2022, Ecuador was hit by heavy rainfall, resulting in multiple landslides, floods, and mudflows. The city of Quito, in particular, experienced devastating losses, with at least 23 people confirmed dead and another 9 missing due to a catastrophic landslide. The tragic event left 47 others injured, and rescue operations are ongoing."

On February 1, 2022, a failed coup attempt was made in Guinea-Bissau resulting in the deaths of "many" members of the security forces, according to President Umaro Sissoco Embalo. Despite the president's statement, the situation is said to be "under control." The African Union and the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) have both condemned the attempt on democracy. In a statement, ECOWAS calls for a peaceful resolution and urges the military to return to their barracks and maintain a republican posture.

Over 60 people were brutally stabbed to death by CODECO militants in Plaine Savo, a camp for internally displaced people in Djugu territory, Ituri Province, DR Congo on February 2, 2022. The victims were residents of the camp, which is home to around 4,000 people. The incident is the latest in a series of attacks in the region, where ethnic violence has been on the rise, causing the displacement of thousands of people. CODECO is a local militia group that is mainly composed of members of the Lendu ethnic group, which has been engaged in deadly clashes with the Hema ethnic group for over two decades. The authorities have condemned the attack and pledged to bring the perpetrators to justice.

UPDATED VERSION:
Whaling in Iceland, which began as spear-drift hunting in the 12th century, has been largely in decline since the late 19th century due to other countries introducing modern commercial practices. Today, Iceland is one of the few countries still officially objecting to the moratorium established by the International Whaling Commission in 1986 and maintaining a whaling fleet. However, the only company that previously hunted minke whales for domestic consumption has announced the end of the practice in 2020, as the meat was no longer popular with tourists. One company still hunts fin whales, mainly for export to Japan. In 2018, Icelandic whalers faced accusations of slaughtering a blue whale. The whaling industry in Iceland has been on hold since 2019, amid coronavirus restrictions, increased competition from subsidized Japanese whaling, and rising domestic whale watching tourism that have undermined the industry. In the latest development, Iceland has announced plans to permanently end whaling by 2024, citing the declining price of whale meat as the reason behind the decision. The country's whale watching sector exists in tension with the whaling industry.

The Jihadist insurgency in Burkina Faso, an ongoing war and civil conflict between the Government of Burkina Faso and Islamist rebels, continues to generate violence and instability in the country. Recently, four civilians were killed during a battle between French troops and Ansar ul Islam, a jihadist group particularly active at the border territories of Mali and Burkina Faso. The clash resulted in the death of ten militants and involved support from an attack helicopter. Amidst the ongoing conflict, a humanitarian crisis has emerged with thousands of people killed and displaced by both sides, with government forces also being accused of summarily executing countless of civilians, disproportionately targeting ethnic Fulani. The UNHCR estimates that six in ten displaced people in

In a major shift, the Canadian Armed Forces has withdrawn its military advisors from Ukraine and relocated them to an undisclosed destination in Europe, while moving its diplomatic staff to Lviv and suspending all operations at its embassy in Kyiv. The move marks a departure from Canada's long-standing involvement in Operation Unifier, which was initiated in 2015 to support Ukraine's efforts in maintaining security, democracy, and economic stability in the face of Russian-backed separatist movements. Canada's decision reflects the growing tensions between Ukraine and Russia, with NATO countries increasingly concerned about the potential for a full-scale conflict. The withdrawal of Canadian troops from Ukraine is likely to have a significant impact on the country's military capabilities and may hamper its ability to resist Russian aggression.

The Rule of Law Conditionality Regulation of the European Union and Euratom has been confirmed by the European Court of Justice to comply with EU treaties, dismissing legal challenges from Poland and Hungary. The regulation enables the European Commission to suspend funds from the EU budget to member states that violate the rule of law principles in article 2 of the Treaty on European Union. Following this decision, the Commission is now able to take measures against member states with rule of law issues that are likely to affect the management of EU funds. The European Parliament has previously urged the Commission to avoid delaying implementation and provide more information on investigations into breaches of rule of law principles.

Australia's fight against terrorism continues as the Australian government designates new organisations as terrorist organisations. The recent additions to the list of designated terrorist organisations include the entirety of Hamas, including its political wing, Atomwaffen Division, Tahrir al-Sham and the Guardians of Religion Organization. The Australian Parliament passed the Security Legislation Amendment (Terrorism) Act 2002, which allows the government to deal with organisations involved in terrorism and insert a range of terrorist organisation offences into the Criminal Code Act 1995 (Cth). Financial transactions involving listed terrorist organisations are monitored by the Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre (AUSTRAC). The list of designated terror organisations, maintained by the Attorney-General's Department, is updated regularly, and listing, de-listing, and re-listing follows a protocol primarily involving the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and the Attorney-General's Department. The responsibility of prosecuting offences sanctions persons and entities under Australian and international law, including new listings such as Atomwaffen Division, Tahrir al-Sham, Guardians of Religion Organization, and the entirety of Hamas as a terrorist organisation.
